To quote the mantra of the excellent Shop Talk Show podcast "Just Build Websites!" In that vein, I‚Äôve got some ideas for sites to build for the sole purpose of putting them in my portfolio. My first portfolio project, a search engine, is in progress.

I‚Äôm working on a page that displays thumbnail images. When I click on a thumbnail I want it to show an info box containing more image details. I‚Äôm using a CSS transition on the info box and I want to populate the image details while the info box is hidden. If the info box is already visible from clicking on a different thumbnail, I need to hide it first and populate the image details after the transition completes.

Here‚Äôs some pseudocode that shows what I want to happen‚Ä¶

thumbnail.addEventListener('click', e => {
  if (infoBox.isVisible()) {
    // hide the info box (CSS transition)
    // after the transition ends, populate the image details
  } else {
    // populate the image details immediately
  }

  // show the info box (CSS transition)
})

The browser triggers a transitionend event when a transition finishes, but it‚Äôs not fired at all if the info box is already hidden. A function that hides the element and returns a Promise would be ideal. The Promise would be resolved after the transition completed or immediately if theinfo box was already hidden, but I don‚Äôt use JavaScript to hide or show an element. I typically just toggle a hidden class and let the CSS animation do the work, so we can‚Äôt determine when the animation has completed.

I can‚Äôt just return a Promise from the event handler for transitionend because I don‚Äôt call the event handler. I just pass it as an argument to addEventListener() and the browser calls it. But there‚Äôs always a way‚Ä¶

I searched for promises for CSS transition events, but the higher ranking search result has a fatal flaw. In a pen1 entitled ‚ÄúCSS Transition End with a Promise‚Äù, a Promise is resolved when the transition completes, but the event handler is never removed from the element. The code attempts to remove the handler, but removeEventListener() is passed a function that wasn‚Äôt attached as the event handler. The actual event handler is an anonymous function that calls the function which the author tries to remove. If you use this code it could eventually cause a problem (What kind of problem? How soon? ‚Ä¶ this needs testing) as new event handlers are infinitely attached to the element.

I found a good solution on my second attempt at this Gist). The trick is a function that returns a Promise and makes a CSS (or CSS class) change that causes a transition, then immediately attaches an event handler for the transitionend event in which it removes itself and resolves the promise.
